questions.question: What is the formula for the compound 1·4CH3OH?
questions.answer: C46Dy2H48N9NaO8S8

questions.question: What are the space groups for the compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: 1·4CH3OH is in the C2/c space group, 2a·sol is in the P21/c space group, and 2b·sol is in the P21/n space group.

questions.question: What is the coordination environment around Dy(III) ion in complexes 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: The coordination environment around Dy(III) ion in complexes 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol is an O4S4 coordination environment.

questions.question: How does the geometry of the [DyL4]- unit differ between compound 1·4CH3OH and compounds 2a·sol and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: The [DyL4]- unit in compound 1·4CH3OH has a triangular dodecahedron geometry, while in compounds 2a·sol and 2b·sol, it has a biaugmented trigonal prism geometry.

questions.question: Based on the magnetic measurements, what phenomenon is observed for compound 2 at zero dc field?
questions.answer: At zero dc field, compound 2 shows an obvious temperature-independent relaxation known as the quantum tunneling process.

questions.question: What is the predicted energy barrier for the Orbach process in compounds 1 and 2 according to ab initio calculations?
questions.answer: The predicted energy barrier for the Orbach process is 287 cm-1 for compound 1 and 303 cm-1 for compound 2.

questions.question: Is the main magnetic axis of the ground Kramers doublet for Dy in compounds 1 and 2 parallel to the shortest coordination bond?
questions.answer: Yes, the main magnetic axis of the ground Kramers doublet for Dy in compounds 1 and 2 is nearly parallel to the shortest coordination bond.

questions.question: Does the relaxation time for the quantum tunneling process at the ground state for compound 2 closely match the experimental value?
questions.answer: Yes, the computed relaxation time for the quantum tunneling process at the ground state for compound 2 is close to the experimental value.

questions.question: Are the compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol air-stable?
questions.answer: Yes, the compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol are described as air-stable.

questions.question: Does the presence of sulfur atoms in the coordination environment of Dy(III) ion in compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol contribute to their magnetic properties?
questions.answer: Yes, the presence of sulfur atoms in the coordination environment of Dy(III) ion in compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol contributes to their magnetic properties.

questions.question: What is the effect of applying a dc field on the magnetic dynamics of compounds 1 and 2?
questions.answer: Applying a dc field suppresses the quantum tunneling process and reveals a Raman process with observable temperature-dependent relaxations for both compounds 1 and 2.

questions.question: What strategy is suggested for constructing air-stable superior S-ligated Dy–SMMs with high coordination numbers?
questions.answer: The strategy involves keeping the soft donor sulfur atoms in the equatorial plane to weaken the equatorial contribution, choosing hard donor atoms along the axial direction to enhance axial magnetic anisotropy, and controlling the local symmetry to suppress zero-field quantum tunneling.

questions.question: Are the compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol based on the same ligand?
questions.answer: Yes, the compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol are based on the same ligand, 2-pyridinethiol 1-oxide (HL).

questions.question: Do compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol share the same anionic unit?
questions.answer: Yes, compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol share the same anionic unit, [DyL4]-.

questions.question: Is the relaxation process in compounds 1 and 2 at zero dc field the same?
questions.answer: No, compound 2 shows a temperature-independent relaxation process known as quantum tunneling at zero dc field, while compound 1 exhibits a faster relaxation without a visible peak.

questions.question: What is the role of the Na+ ion in the structure of compounds 2a·sol and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: In compounds 2a·sol and 2b·sol, the Na+ ion coordinates to oxygen and sulfur atoms from the ligands, bridging the [DyL4]- units and forming a zig-zag one-dimensional chain.

questions.question: What is the significance of the shortest coordination bond around Dy3+ ion in compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: The shortest coordination bond around Dy3+ ion, which is between Dy3+ and the non-bridged oxygen atom, is significant for the magnetic properties of the compounds, as it is nearly parallel to the main magnetic axis of the ground Kramers doublet.

questions.question: Do compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol exhibit single-molecule magnet behavior?
questions.answer: Yes, compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol exhibit single-molecule magnet behavior, with differences in their magnetic dynamics.

questions.question: What is the effect of the coordination geometry on the magnetic dynamics of compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol?
questions.answer: The coordination geometry, specifically the transition from triangular dodecahedron geometry in 1·4CH3OH to biaugmented trigonal prism geometry in 2a·sol and 2b·sol, directly affects the magnetic dynamics, leading to different relaxation processes.

questions.question: Are the magnetic properties of compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol influenced by their structural differences?
questions.answer: Yes, the magnetic properties of compounds 1·4CH3OH, 2a·sol, and 2b·sol are influenced by their structural differences, including the coordination geometry and the presence of the Na+ ion.
